title: Judgment on Egypt
shortSummary: Jeremiah 46 contains a prophetic oracle against Egypt, foretelling its defeat by Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon. The chapter vividly describes the military downfall of Egypt and assures God's people Israel of future restoration and protection despite the surrounding nations' judgment.
timeline: c. 605 BC - During the early Babylonian Empire, in the fourth year of Jehoiakim king of Judah

keyCharacters.name: Jeremiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet through whom God delivers the message of judgment against Egypt and hope for Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Pharaoh Necho
keyCharacters.description: King of Egypt whose army is defeated by Nebuchadnezzar as prophesied.

keyCharacters.name: Nebuchadnezzar
keyCharacters.description: King of Babylon who conquers Egypt, fulfilling God's judgment.

keyCharacters.name: Jacob (Israel)
keyCharacters.description: God’s servant and the nation of Israel, promised salvation and restoration despite judgment on surrounding nations.

A healing ointment or resin used medicinally, symbolizing attempts to heal Egypt’s wounds in vain.
An ancient name for the city of Thebes in Egypt, representing the Egyptian nation.

outline.heading: Introduction and Context of Judgment
outline.description: The chapter opens with the Lord’s word to Jeremiah concerning the Gentiles, specifically Egypt, and sets the historical context of Nebuchadnezzar’s victory over Pharaoh Necho’s army.

outline.heading: The Call to Prepare for Battle and Egypt’s Defeat
outline.description: A vivid military summons describes Egypt’s preparation for battle and its ensuing panic and defeat, emphasizing God’s sovereign control over the outcome.

outline.heading: The Prophecy of Egypt’s Fall
outline.description: Jeremiah proclaims the certainty of Babylon’s conquest of Egypt, the desolation of key cities, and the futility of relying on human strength or idols.

outline.heading: God’s Promise to Israel
outline.description: The chapter concludes with a message of hope and reassurance to Israel, promising deliverance from captivity and correction rather than destruction.

application: Trust in God's sovereign plan even when surrounding nations or circumstances seem powerful and threatening.
Recognize the futility of relying on human strength or worldly alliances instead of God’s protection and guidance.
Take comfort in God's promises of restoration and peace for His people despite trials and discipline.
Respond to God's correction with humility and faith, knowing He disciplines those He loves rather than abandoning them.

keyVerses.text: For this is the day of the Lord GOD of hosts, a day of vengeance, that he may avenge him of his adversaries: and the sword shall devour, and it shall be satiate and made drunk with their blood: for the Lord GOD of hosts hath a sacrifice in the north country by the river Euphrates.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's righteous judgment and sovereign vengeance against Egypt, affirming His control over history.

keyVerses.text: But fear not thou, O my servant Jacob, and be not dismayed, O Israel: for, behold, I will save thee from afar off, and thy seed from the land of their captivity; and Jacob shall return, and be in rest and at ease, and none shall make him afraid.
keyVerses.significance: A comforting promise of salvation and restoration to Israel, assuring God's faithfulness to His covenant people.

keyVerses.text: Fear thou not, O Jacob my servant, saith the LORD: for I am with thee; for I will make a full end of all the nations whither I have driven thee: but I will not make a full end of thee, but correct thee in measure; yet will I not leave thee wholly unpunished.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reassures Israel of God's presence and measured discipline, emphasizing His merciful correction rather than total destruction.
